abstract: Jeremy Stoppelman, a co-founder of review site Yelp and its chief executive, has seen the tables of Web 2.0 turned against his company as angry business owners have taken to Internet boards to pan Yelp. The New York Times’s Kermit Pattison sat down for a chat with Mr. Stoppelman.
snippet: Jeremy Stoppelman, a co-founder of review site Yelp and its chief executive, has seen the tables of Web 2.0 turned against his company as angry business owners have taken to Internet boards to pan Yelp. The New York Times’s Kermit Pattison sat dow...
lead_paragraph: Yelp! What happens when an online review site itself becomes the subject of harsh public scrutiny? Such is the case of Yelp, the review site with the motto, “Real People. Real reviews.” In recent weeks, Yelp has been hit with three class-action lawsuits from businesses claiming that Yelp sales representatives tried to press the businesses into advertising by offering — or threatening — to manipulate reviews.

headline.main: Yelp Chief on Site That Businesses Love to Hate

abstract: Google has stopped censoring results on its Chinese search engine, but many underlying pages are still blocked. Meanwhile, some Chinese say Google risks a government shutdown of its service, which would deprive them of its benefits on all topics.
snippet: Google has stopped censoring results on its Chinese search engine, but many underlying pages are still blocked. Meanwhile, some Chinese say Google risks a government shutdown of its service, which would deprive them of its benefits on all topics.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As Google began offering uncensored search results in China early Tuesday morning, it was unclear how much impact the company’s move would have toward the company’s stated goal: to “meaningfully increase access to information for people in China.”

headline.main: What Happens as Google Uncensors Search in China?
